is a city of 40 000 people in
.  Located about an hour north of the
border, Brandon is the second-largest city in the province, after
.  Brandon is known as a city that is not too big to be impersonal, but not so small that it lacks the amenities of large cities.
Although Brandon has a municipal airport, limited commercial passenger service is available. Perimeter Air
is the only airline offering passenger service to Dauphin and

. The Winnipeg International Airport is located approximately 200 km to the east of Brandon and is well connected with flights across Canada. Travelers can fly into Winnipeg and then transfer to ground transportation to reach Brandon. The Brandon Air Shuttle
provides daily transportation from Winnipeg International Airport to locations in Brandon. The shuttle will pick up and drop off at any location in Brandon.

and Grey Goose bus lines runs several bus routes through Brandon.  The Brandon bus terminal is located at 141 6th Street in the downtown core and is open 7 days a week. Buses departed for destinations such as Winnipeg, Portage la Prairie, Regina, Saskatoon, Calgary, and Vancouver. The bus terminal features a restaurant, locker storage, and vending machines.
Brandon is at the junction of the Trans Canada Highway and Highway 10.  Highway 10 south is a direct connection to
(USA).  The US and Canada customs offices on this highway operate 24 hours.  The Trans Canada Highway that goes eastbound to

serves the city of Brandon through the train station in Rivers, located 30 km north of Brandon on Highway 10. The Via Station in Rivers is a limited stop service for trains on the Toronto-Vancouver line. Trains heading west depart on Monday, Thursday, and Saturday at 15:13 and trains heading east depart on Tuesday, Friday, and Sunday at 16:30.

operates ten bus routes throughout the city. The Brandon Transit website provides a map of the routes. Buses depart every 30 minutes during peak times and every hour during non-peak times. Limited public transit is available on Sundays.
The city has no shortage of taxi companies. Fares are metered and based on rates set by the city.
Two car rental agencies are located in the city and prices are approximately the same throughout the city. Many rental agency offices are not open on Sundays.

value: content=Home to self-guided trails around the Assiniboine River, tourism information on the city, and canoe/kayak rentals.
content=Annual event held in mid July on the grounds of the Keystone Centre. Opportunity to hear music from across many different genres. Family friendly event.
content=Canada's largest indoor Agricultural Trade Show and Program. Held in mid January each year at Brandon's Keystone Centre.
content=The Royal Manitoba Winter Fair is one of Western Canadaâ€™s largest agricultural events and the largest annual event to be held in Brandon. Held annually at the end of March.
content=Fair is held annually in early June.

content=The Jazz festival brings over 3,000 performers to the city from across Canada and the USA. The day is dominated by high school performances and workshops while the evenings are concerts. Event held annually in mid March.
content=8 lanes of fivepin and 12 lanes of tenpin bowling.  Home of Huggy's Restaurant, Huggy's Lounge, and Pizza Place.
directions=23 km east of Brandon on PR 457/340.
content=One of Western Manitoba's sternest tests of golf and home of many area tournaments.
directions=Located just N of Trans Canada Hwy

content=A nine-hole golf course with large greens, Deer Ridge offers one par 5 and two challenging par 3 holes. Easy to walk and can be played in under two hours, it is great for both local residents and travellers alike.
content=The Brandon Wheat Kings of the Western Hockey League play hockey games from October - April at the Keystone Centre.
content=The Brandon University Bobcats volleyball and basketball teams  host games on weekends from October - March.
content=Brandon's major shopping mall is anchored by Zellers and Safeway.
content=Brandon's first power centre includes Wal-Mart, Safeway, Home Depot, Michael's, and Future Shop.  There are several other shops and services.
content=A rare vintage outdoor service Dairy Queen.
content=One of Brandon's original ice cream shops.
content=A new ice cream bar in a retro 50's theme.
content=Brandon's premier restaurant for Chinese food.
content=Home of the "Marino's Classic", Brandon's best pizza.
content=This country like bar features bands and a large dance floor.
content=The Double Decker is a tavern featuring a large eating section and a menu full of pub food. They also have a bar section that often features live bands.
content=Clancy's is a two story eatery/pub. The upstairs and certain other rooms are designated for eating, while others are designated bar space.
content=New hotel attached to the Keystone Centre. Convenient if you plan to attend an event at the Keystone.

: Located approximately 100 km north of Brandon. Greyhound bus provides daily buses between Brandon and Wasagaming (townsite located within the park).
: Located approximately 60 km south east of Brandon. No public transit is available to Spruce Woods.
: Approximately 40 km south of Brandon. Canada's longest Swinging Bridge is in Souris.
The featured destination of Spruce Woods Provincial Park. Home to Manitoba's only open sand dunes.
